    <item>
      <title>Trump meets Florida survivors as shooting suspect plans to plead guilty</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/trump-florida-parkland-school-shooting-guns</link>
      <description><p>President praises response to shooting while public defender says Nikolas Cruz will plead guilty to 17 counts of first-degree murder</p><p>Donald Trump visited a Florida hospital on Friday night to meet survivors of this week’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/florida-school-shooting">deadly high school shooting</a>, as the local public defender said the suspect would plead guilty.<br></p><p>“It’s very sad something like this could happen,” Trump told reporters at Broward Health North hospital. “But the job the doctors did, the nurses, the hospital, the first responders, law enforcement, was really incredible.”<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/trump-florida-parkland-school-shooting-guns">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mueller charges 13 Russians with interfering in US election to help Trump</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/robert-mueller-russians-charged-election</link>
      <description><p>DoJ indictment alleges Russian operatives ‘communicated with unwitting individuals associated with the Trump campaign’</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/russians-indictment-mueller-charges-fbi-investigation-what-are-they">Ten key takeaways from the Mueller indictment</a></li></ul><p>Thirteen Russians have been criminally charged for interfering in the 2016 US election to help Donald Trump, the office of Robert Mueller, the special counsel, announced on Friday.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2017/dec/08/donald-trump-russia-investigation-key-questions-latest-news-collusion-timeline">Trump-Russia investigation: the key questions answered</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/robert-mueller-russians-charged-election">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Nuclear risk at its highest since Cuban missile crisis, says ex-energy secretary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/15/nuclear-weapons-ernest-moniz-accident-risk</link>
      <description><p>Nuclear physicist Ernest Moniz says world has been lucky to avoid accidental weapon launch – and risk is growing</p><p>The world has been lucky so far to escape the launch of nuclear weapons through miscalculation, but the odds of such a catastrophic accident are increasing, according to the former US energy secretary Ernest Moniz.<br></p><p>Moniz, a nuclear physicist who played a central role in securing a landmark non-proliferation agreement with Iran in 2015, said the margin for error in avoiding disaster was getting thinner because of the introduction of new, smaller weapons, the broadening of circumstances in which their use is being contemplated, and a lack of high-level communications between major nuclear weapons powers.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/15/nuclear-weapons-ernest-moniz-accident-risk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Dreamers stuck in limbo as Senate rejects four immigration plans</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/dreamers-daca-senate-vote-rejects-trump-immigration-plan</link>
      <description><p>Defeat of separate proposals suggests there may be no permanent solution soon for young undocumented immigrants<br></p><p>The Senate left hundreds of thousands of Dreamers in limbo Thursday, rejecting rival plans that would have spared them from deportation and strengthened the nation’s border security. </p><p>The day’s votes, in which four separate proposals were defeated, illustrated anew Congress’ steep challenge in striking a deal on an issue that’s proven intractable for years and on which each party’s most fervent supporters refuse to budge. The outcome suggested there may be no permanent solution soon to help the Dreamers – young, undocumented immigrants who were brought to the US as children – despite their sky-high support in public polling.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/dreamers-daca-senate-vote-rejects-trump-immigration-plan">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Mitt Romney, Trump critic on the right, announces Senate run in Utah</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/mitt-romney-senate-run-trump-critic</link>
      <description><p>The 2012 presidential candidate has condemned Trump – but a former spokesman says Romney will side with the president 80% of the time</p><p>Former Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney announced his candidacy for a US Senate seat in Utah, marking a return to politics for one of the president’s fiercest conservative critics.</p><p>“I have decided to run for United States Senate because I believe I can help bring Utah’s values and Utah’s lessons to Washington,” Romney said in a video released online Friday. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/mitt-romney-senate-run-trump-critic">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>US tribe fights use of treated sewage to make snow on holy peaks</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/15/arizona-snow-ski-hopi-tribe-lawsuit</link>
      <description><p>The Hopi tribe is taking on an Arizona ski resort over its use of artificial snow: ‘People compare it to baptizing a baby with reclaimed water’</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jan/29/this-land-is-your-land-series-the-guardian">As threat to America’s public land increases, so does our coverage</a></li></ul><p>To the Hopi tribe, the San Francisco Peaks are sacred. The cluster of mountains rise dramatically from grasslands and ponderosa forests in northern Arizona, and the Hopi say they are home to spiritual beings called kachinas, believed to bring the rain and snow to their reservation.</p><p>But the tribe has been allowed to move forward with a lawsuit against a local ski resort over what the tribe deems to be a desecration of the holy mountains: spraying artificial snow made from treated sewage.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/15/arizona-snow-ski-hopi-tribe-lawsuit">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Admiral warns US must prepare for possibility of war with China</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/16/admiral-warns-us-must-prepare-for-possibility-of-war-with-china</link>
      <description><p>Harry Harris, the next US ambassador to Australia, says Beijing intends to control South China Sea</p><p>The <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/10/admiral-harry-harris-named-us-ambassador-to-australia">navy admiral nominated to be the next US ambassador to Australia</a> has told Congress America must prepare for the possibility of war with China, and said it would rely on Australia to help uphold the international rules-based system in the Asia-Pacific.</p><p>In an excoriating assessment of China’s increasingly muscular posture in the region, Harry Harris said Beijing’s “intent is crystal clear” to dominate the South China Sea and that its military might could soon rival American power “across almost every domain”. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/16/admiral-warns-us-must-prepare-for-possibility-of-war-with-china">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>American success story: how Ryan Murphy became Netflix's $300m man</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2018/feb/16/ryan-murphy-netflix</link>
      <description><p>The creator and executive producer of shows such as Glee and American Horror Story will be moving to Netflix in a landmark deal. But what turned him into the most powerful show-runner in Hollywood?</p><p>Ryan Murphy, the prodigious television workhorse, is now Netflix’s $300m man. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2018/feb/14/ryan-murphy-joins-netflix-in-unprecedented-mega-deal">The news on Tuesday</a> that the streaming giant had acquired Murphy’s services with a hefty five-year deal shook up the television industry, with one of its foremost auteurs announcing his plan to flee the coop of 20th Century Fox TV for Netflix come summertime.</p><p>The pact includes plans for television series, feature films and documentaries, and marks what’s believed to be the most lucrative contract in television history. And that’s after the streaming service lured Shonda Rhimes away from ABC with a four-year deal worth an estimated $100m last August.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2018/feb/16/ryan-murphy-netflix">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/17/american-democracy-four-pillars-activism-arlie-hochschild</link>
      <description><p>The simple act of crossing the partisan divide will not resolve our crisis. But it could help us begin to slowly rebuild our nation</p><p>Ever since Donald Trump captured the imagination of enough American voters to win, liberals I’ve spoken with have felt in a quandary. Trump seems to be kicking at the foundation of democracy itself, and the Democratic party has yet to reinvent itself into a powerful, coherent alternative. <br></p><p>Some progressives have become highly anxious or depressed, and quit reading the newspapers in an effort to escape such feelings. Others have plunged into work with coalition-oriented groups – such as Indivisible or MoveOn.Org – or have joined single-issue groups such as Black Lives Matter.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/17/american-democracy-four-pillars-activism-arlie-hochschild">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The media exaggerates negative news. This distortion has consequences | Steven Pinker</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/17/steven-pinker-media-negative-news</link>
      <description><p>Whether or not the world really is getting worse, the nature of news will make us think that it is</p><p>Every day the news is filled with stories about war, terrorism, crime, pollution, inequality, drug abuse and oppression. And it’s not just the headlines we’re talking about; it’s the op-eds and long-form stories as well. Magazine covers warn us of coming anarchies, plagues, epidemics, collapses, and so many “crises” (farm, health, retirement, welfare, energy, deficit) that copywriters have had to escalate to the redundant “serious crisis.” </p><p>Whether or not the world really is getting worse, the nature of news will interact with the nature of cognition to make us think that it is. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/17/steven-pinker-media-negative-news">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Please park the tired ‘unlucky-in-love’ Jennifer Aniston storyline | Barbara Ellen</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/please-park-unlucky-in-love-jennifer-aniston-storyline</link>
      <description><p>The film star has announced her separation from Justin Theroux. The response to her perfectly normal relationship trajectory is entirely predictable</p><p>The marriage of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/jennifer-aniston" title="">Jennifer Aniston</a> and Justin Theroux has ended “lovingly”. How does that even work? “Get out of my life! (I love you).” “I never want to see your miserable face again (You lit up my world).” “Don’t pack my coffee maker – you thief! (We will always have Paris).” However, Aniston and Theroux are managing it and good luck to them. I wish them well in what may be their last shared quest not to end up becoming as annoying and smug as Gwyneth Paltrow and Chris&nbsp;Martin, the celebrity couple who inadvertently proved that there <em>can</em> be such a thing as an over-civilised divorce.</p><p>In particular, good luck to Aniston, who, though she’s done a bit of acting, must now return to her proper day job of being described as “unlucky in love” in eight out of 10 articles written about her, the ninth usually written about her <a href="http://www.cosmopolitan.com/entertainment/celebs/a18208903/jennifer-aniston-brad-pitt-tweets/" title="">getting back with Brad Pitt</a> (after approximately 13 years apart) and the tenth rudely insinuating that she is too old for bikinis.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/please-park-unlucky-in-love-jennifer-aniston-storyline">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is there any hope for truth? I went to a conference to find out | Rhik Samadder</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/is-there-any-hope-for-truth-i-went-to-a-conference-to-find-out</link>
      <description><p>From bot factories weaponising misinformation to Twitter trolls polluting online debate, we are all living in a fake news world – unless, it turns out, you are a teen</p><p>Have we destroyed truth? How can we live in a fake news world? When will The Experts Strike Back? To find out, I blagged my way into an academic event, looking for answers. <a href="https://www.knowledgequarter.london/kq-conference-2018/future-of-knowledge-2018/">The Future of Knowledge</a> was hosted by Knowledge Quarter, an assembly of organisations in the King’s Cross area that includes Soas, the British Library, the British Museum and the Institute of Physics – a bit like <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2011/sep/22/your-next-box-set-avengers">The Avengers</a>.</p><p>On one of the panels was historian and film-maker <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/profile/david-olusoga">David Olusoga</a>, the smartest, most miserable man I have ever heard speak. “The historian Oswald Spengler said that optimism is cowardice,” he began. He went on to draw parallels between now and the 1920s, both being characterised by a flight from reason and the rise of propaganda. Our age is different, he said, because it is worse. He is right. Social media – anonymous, empowering and narcissistic – has polluted our debates. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/02/putin-kremlin-inside-russian-troll-house">Bot factories in Russia have weaponised misinformation</a>, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/03/donald-trump-boasts-nuclear-button-bigger-kim-jong-un">Trump edges us closer to nuclear extinction with a tweet</a>, yet after a hard weekend hitting the Häagen-Dazs I can’t post a picture of my nipples on Instagram? I have lost track of what I was saying. That is another thing: <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/05/crimes-of-attention-stalkers-killers-jihadists-longing">we all have shorter attention spans</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/is-there-any-hope-for-truth-i-went-to-a-conference-to-find-out">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Gus Kenworthy's kiss with boyfriend on NBC greeted with acclaim</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/gus-kenworthy-kiss-boyfriend-olympics</link>
      <description><p>The British-born American freestyle skier failed to add to his silver from Sochi, but a historic kiss with his boyfriend on primetime network TV may have made an even bigger impact back home</p><p>When the American freestyle skier Gus Kenworthy shared a kiss with boyfriend Matthew Wilkas at the bottom of the hill before Sunday morning’s ski slopestyle qualifying, neither was immediately aware the moment was captured by NBC’s cameras.</p><p>But the significance of an openly gay male athlete kissing another man on primetime network television during one of the world’s biggest collective experiences was not lost on the Saturday night audience back home in the United States where it quickly went viral and was feted by LGBT activists as a marker of progress amid the <a href="https://www.outsports.com/2018/2/9/16997928/nbc-winter-olympics-lgbt-opening-ceremony">broadcaster’s much-criticized handling</a> of gay athletes.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/gus-kenworthy-kiss-boyfriend-olympics">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Controversy in the women’s curling as GB lose to Sweden; GB men beat Italy; James Woods finishes fourth in the slopestyle final; and Martin Fourcade of France took the mass biathlon in an amazing finish</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-18T14:26:56.827Z">2.26pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/christie-in-doubt-for-1000m-speed-skating-heats-with-ankle-damage">Elise Christie hopeful of competing in 1000m short-track despite injury</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/gus-kenworthy-kiss-boyfriend-olympics">Gus Kenworthy's kiss with boyfriend on NBC greeted with acclaim</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/great-britains-woods-falls-agonisingly-short-in-ski-slopestyle">Great Britain's Woods falls agonisingly short in ski slopestyle</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/winter-olympics-russian-athlete-reportedly-fails-drugs-test">Russian athlete reportedly fails Winter Olympics drugs test</a> </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-18T14:13:10.039Z">2.13pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p><strong>Right, there we are: day nine is in the books. </strong>Join us again tomorrow and enjoy what’s left of the weekend! </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/live/2018/feb/18/winter-olympics-2018-day-nine-from-pyeongchang-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>NHL fans ejected for racist taunts at Capitals' Devante Smith-Pelly</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/devante-smith-pelly-chicago-blackhawks-racist-taunts</link>
      <description><ul><li>Fans shouted ‘basketball, basketball, basketball’ at player</li><li>Canadian has spoken of loneliness of being a hockey player </li></ul><p>Devante Smith-Pelly was taunted by four fans shouting “basketball, basketball, basketball” on Saturday night during the Chicago Blackhawks’ game against the Washington Capitals.</p><p>Washington’s Smith-Pelly, who is black, was serving a major penalty for fighting Chicago’s Connor Murphy when the fans taunted him in the penalty box. An off-ice official sitting next to him notified building security, and the fans were ejected. Smith-Pelly was visibly upset by the taunting, at one point tapping the glass separating him from the fans.&nbsp;</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/devante-smith-pelly-chicago-blackhawks-racist-taunts">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Russians outclass USA in men's ice hockey in front of fiery crowd</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/usa-oar-ice-hockey-winter-olympics</link>
      <description><ul><li>Americans easily beaten by old rivals at Gangneung Hockey Centre</li><li>US face qualification playoff to make quarter-finals</li><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/13/winter-olympics-ice-hockey-nhl">Did the NHL kill men’s hockey at the Winter Olympics?</a></li></ul><p>Ilya Kovalchuk scored two back-breaking goals as the Russians outplayed, outhit and outclassed the United States in a convincing 4-0 shutout on Saturday night as each team wrapped up pool play at the Olympics.</p><p>Saturday night lacked the tense political subtext of the Cold War <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2018/02/08/remember-when-team-usa-defeats-soviet-union-miracle-ice/1052092001/">from the famous ‘Miracle on Ice’ 1980 meeting</a> and the pomp and circumstance of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2014/feb/15/sochi-2014-olympic-hockey-usa-defeat-russia-shootout">Russian president Vladimir Putin attending in Sochi in 2014</a>, but it had the same kind of in-arena atmosphere. US and Russian fans filled Gangneung Hockey Centre and went back and forth with “U-S-A” and the “ROSS-I-YA” chants that made up the background noise at the Olympics four years ago.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/usa-oar-ice-hockey-winter-olympics">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/donald-trump-fbi-russia-inquiry-florida-shooting</link>
      <description><p>The president’s attempt to use the shooting to make a political point about the Russia inquiries drew swift criticism</p><p>Donald Trump has criticized the FBI for missing the “many signals” about the Florida school shooter, saying the agency was spending “too much time” trying to prove Russian collusion with the Trump campaign. <br></p><p>The US president’s attempt to use the shooting to make a political point about the FBI’s Russia inquiries into the Trump campaign drew swift criticism, including from John Kasich, the Republican governor of Ohio, who told CNN it was an “absurd statement”. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/donald-trump-fbi-russia-inquiry-florida-shooting">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/donald-trump-hr-mcmaster-russia-election-meddling-investigation</link>
      <description><p>HR McMaster calls evidence incontrovertible in wake of latest US indictments against more than a dozen Russians </p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/robert-mueller-russians-charged-election">Mueller charges 13 Russians with interfering in US election to help Trump</a></li></ul><p>Donald Trump’s national security adviser, HR McMaster, said on Saturday that Russian meddling in the 2016 election is “incontrovertible” and “beyond dispute” in the wake of new US indictments.</p><p>McMaster spoke after Robert Mueller, the special counsel in the Russia investigation, revealed new details about Moscow’s sophisticated cyber-meddling campaign on Friday.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/donald-trump-hr-mcmaster-russia-election-meddling-investigation">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>NRA contributions: how much money is spent on lawmakers?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/florida-school-shooting-focus-shifts-to-nra-gun-lobby-cash-to-lawmakers</link>
      <description><p>Anger as Republicans Paul Ryan, Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio call for prayers for victims rather than action on gun control</p><p>In the minutes and hours after a <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/how-the-florida-high-school-shooting-unfolded-students-gunman">teenage gunman killed 17 people</a> at a high school in Parkland, Florida, politicians began what has become something of a grim ritual following mass shootings: they offered “thoughts and prayers” to the victims and their families. </p><p>The response, as it has in the past, drew fierce criticism from Democrats and supporters of stricter gun control legislation, who view the condolences as woefully inadequate as mass shootings become more frequent and more lethal. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/florida-school-shooting-focus-shifts-to-nra-gun-lobby-cash-to-lawmakers">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Florida shooting: suspect escaped scene by hiding among students as they fled</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/florida-shooting-suspect-charged-questions-nikolas-cruz</link>
      <description><p>Nikolas Cruz, 19, charged with 17 counts of murder as officials confirm the AR-15 rifle used to commit massacre was purchased legally</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/donald-trump-florida-shooting-speech-mental-health-gun-control">Trump emphasizes mental health over gun control </a></li><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/florida-shooting-victims-named-family-friends">Victims: friends and family pay tribute to lives cut short</a></li></ul><p>The suspect in the school shooting that left 17 people dead in Parkland, Florida, escaped the scene by dropping his rifle and backpack and mixing in with the crowd of fleeing students, authorities confirmed at a press conference Thursday.</p><p>Officials also confirmed that the AR-15 rifle he used in the massacre was purchased lawfully in Florida by the gunman over a year ago. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/florida-shooting-suspect-charged-questions-nikolas-cruz">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Commerce department presses Trump to impose steep tariffs on overseas steel</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/16/us-commerce-department-trump-steel-aluminium-tariffs</link>
      <description><ul><li>Proposals would fulfil campaign promise to protect US steel</li><li>Brazil, China, Russia, South Korea and Vietnam targeted<br></li></ul><p>The US commerce department has recommended that Donald Trump impose steep curbs on steel and aluminum imports from China and other nations ranging from global and country-specific tariffs to broad import quotas, according to proposals released on Friday.</p><p>The long-awaited proposals would fulfill Trump’s campaign promise to protect the US steel industry from foreign competition, particularly from China.     <item>
      <title>Balfour Beatty to help build new LA airport transport system</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/16/balfour-beatty-build-la-airport-transport-system</link>
      <description><p>UK construction firm has 30% stake in joint venture that won $1.95bn contract</p><p>Balfour Beatty is part of a joint venture that has won a $1.95bn (£1.38bn) contract relating to building, financing and managing a new transport system at Los Angeles international airport (LAX).</p><p>The contract will include designing and building a 2.25-mile (3.6km), above-ground airport transport system to connect LAX central terminal area to a rental car facility, six stations and a vehicle maintenance facility, the UK construction company said in a statement.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/16/balfour-beatty-build-la-airport-transport-system">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Last week’s steep drop in equity prices is fading memory despite predictions of US interest rate hikes</p><p>New evidence of mounting US inflation has failed to derail the recovery from last week’s plunge in share prices, with global stock markets registering fresh gains.</p><p>Last week’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/06/stock-market-fall-correction-crash-shares">steep drop in equity prices</a> was a fading memory as Wall Street shrugged off concerns that mounting cost of living pressures could force the Federal Reserve, the US central bank, into a series of interest rate rises in 2018.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/15/markets-shrug-off-us-inflation-worries-to-make-fresh-gains">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Only the EU can break Facebook and Google's dominance | George Soros</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/15/eu-facebook-google-dominance-george-soros</link>
      <description><p>Social media giants have left the US government impotent – Europe must lead the way <br></p><p>The current moment in world history is a painful one. Open societies are in crisis, and forms of dictatorships and mafia states, exemplified by Vladimir Putin’s Russia, are on the rise. In the United States, President Donald Trump would like to establish his own mafia-style state but cannot, because the constitution, other institutions, and a vibrant civil society won’t allow it.</p><p>Not only is the survival of open society in question; the survival of our entire civilisation is at stake. The rise of leaders such as Kim Jong-un in North Korea and Trump in the US have much to do with this. Both seem willing to risk a nuclear war in order to keep themselves in power. But the root cause goes even deeper. Mankind’s ability to harness the forces of nature, both for constructive and destructive purposes, continues to grow, while our ability to govern ourselves properly fluctuates, and is now at a low ebb.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/15/eu-facebook-google-dominance-george-soros">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Putin’s chef, a troll farm and Russia's plot to hijack US democracy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/putins-chef-a-troll-farm-and-russias-plot-to-hijack-us-democracy</link>
      <description><p>Robert Mueller has revealed audacious meddling in the 2016 election. Can he link it to Trump?</p><p>The plot against America began in 2014. Thousands of miles away, in a drab office building in St Petersburg, Russia, a fake newsroom was under construction with its own graphics, data analysis, search engine optimisation, IT and finance departments. Its mission: ”information warfare against the United States of America”.</p><p>What followed, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/robert-mueller-russians-charged-election">according to an indictment</a> brought by the US special counsel, Robert Mueller, on Friday, was a stunningly successful attack on the most powerful democracy in the world. It involved stolen identities, fake social media accounts, rallies organised from afar, US citizens duped into doing Moscow’s bidding, and two Russians going undercover in a ruse reminiscent of <em>The Americans</em>, a TV drama about KGB spies in suburban Washington during the cold war.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/putins-chef-a-troll-farm-and-russias-plot-to-hijack-us-democracy">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Michelle Obama portrait puts black Baltimore artist in the spotlight</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/michelle-obama-portrait-amy-sherald-baltimore-conversation</link>
      <description>The commission of a lifetime for Amy Sherald has kickstarted a conversation about art, politics and culture<p>She is a Baltimore-based artist who only paints African-American subjects and always uses a muted palette. But last week, Amy Sherald became the art world’s latest sensation as her <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2018/feb/12/barack-obama-michelle-obama-national-portrait-gallery" title="">portrait of former first lady Michelle Obama</a> was unveiled in Washington.</p><p>Sherald, 44, almost didn’t get to paint Obama. She put away her brushes for three years to care for her family in Georgia. Then, in 2012, she collapsed and underwent a heart transplant that meant she needed another year to recuperate.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/michelle-obama-portrait-amy-sherald-baltimore-conversation">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><ul><li>Agency said report should have been investigated thoroughly</li><li>FBI says caller expressed concerns Cruz could attack a school</li><li>Jeff Sessions orders review of federal response to warnings</li></ul><p>The FBI admitted on Friday it failed to investigate a specific report in January that Nikolas Cruz could be plotting a school shooting.</p><p>The agency said the tip should have been investigated thoroughly because it was a “potential threat to life”.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/mar/15/so-america-this-is-how-you-do-gun-control</link>
      <description><p>The UK, Australia, Japan and Germany have all taken measures to reduce gun homicides. Can the US learn anything from them?</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2017/oct/02/america-mass-shootings-gun-violence">America’s gun crisis – in one chart</a><br></li></ul><p>Thirty people will be shot dead in America today. On average. It could be more. If it’s less, then more will die tomorrow. Or the next day.</p><p>The United States’s gun homicide rate is 25 times higher than other high-income countries, <a href="http://www.amjmed.com/article/S0002-9343(15)01030-X/fulltext">according to a recent study</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/mar/15/so-america-this-is-how-you-do-gun-control">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The charge sheet provides powerful new evidence of a Russian plot – but does not name any Americans as alleged co-conspirators</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/robert-mueller-russians-charged-election">Thirteen Russians criminally charged with interfering in US election, Mueller announces</a></li><li><a href="https://www.justice.gov/file/1035477/download">Read the indictment</a><br></li></ul><p>The US justice department on Friday announced that a grand jury convened by special counsel Robert Mueller had <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/robert-mueller-russians-charged-election">indicted 13 Russians and three Russian entities</a> in an alleged conspiracy to defraud the United States, including by tampering in the 2016 presidential election on behalf of Donald Trump and against Hillary Clinton.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/russians-indictment-mueller-charges-fbi-investigation-what-are-they">Ten key takeaways from Mueller's Russia indictment</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/russians-indictment-mueller-charges-fbi-investigation-what-are-they">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Trump 'had affair with former Playboy model', report says</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/trump-affair-karen-mcdougal-playboy-playmate-new-yorker-report</link>
      <description><p>According to the New Yorker, Karen McDougal claims the affair took place in 2006 and that her story was silenced in the months before Trump was elected president</p><p>Donald Trump had an extramarital affair with a woman named Karen McDougal, a Playboy model at the time, according to <a href="https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/donald-trump-a-playboy-model-and-a-system-for-concealing-infidelity-national-enquirer-karen-mcdougal">a report in the New Yorker</a>, which also claims her story was silenced in the months before the businessman was elected president.</p><p>The story was <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/national-enquirer-shielded-donald-trump-from-playboy-models-affair-allegation-1478309380">first reported</a> by the Wall Street Journal in November 2016, though McDougal declined to comment at that time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/trump-affair-karen-mcdougal-playboy-playmate-new-yorker-report">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-news">US news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump">Donald Trump</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration">Trump administration</category>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2018 16:12:13 GMT</pubDate>

    <item>
      <title>Mass shootings: what are the deadliest attacks in the US?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/deadliest-mass-shootings-in-modern-america</link>
      <description><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/florida-shooting-suspect-charged-questions-nikolas-cruz">Florida shooting</a> is worst attack on a high school to date – and of the deadliest 13 mass shootings, nine have occurred post-Columbine </p><p>Columbine was once an instantly understood single-word shorthand for the terrible toll of mass shootings in the United States. But the massacre that happened in Colorado almost 19 years ago is no longer one of the worst 10 mass shootings in modern America. And following the shooting at a high school in Parkland, Florida, Columbine no longer stands as the worst high school shooting in US history.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/deadliest-mass-shootings-in-modern-america">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Most Americans can buy an AR-15 rifle before they can buy beer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/americans-age-to-buy-ar15-assault-rifle-mass-shootings</link>
      <description><p>The military-style gun, the weapon of choice for mass shootings, can be bought in most states starting at the age of 18 </p><p>Americans have to be 21 before they can legally buy alcohol. But in most states, they can buy an AR-15 military-style rifle starting at age 18.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/americans-age-to-buy-ar15-assault-rifle-mass-shootings">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mass shootings in the US: there have been 1,624 in 1,870 days</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2017/oct/02/america-mass-shootings-gun-violence</link>
      <description><p>No other developed nation comes close to the rate of US gun violence. Americans own an estimated <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/sep/19/us-gun-ownership-survey">265m guns</a>, more than one gun for every adult.</p><p>Data from the Gun Violence Archive reveals there is a mass shooting – defined as four or more people shot in one incident, not including the shooter – nine out of every 10 days on average </p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/florida-shooting-suspect-charged-questions-nikolas-cruz">The latest on the Florida school shooting</a></li></ul> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2017/oct/02/america-mass-shootings-gun-violence">Continue reading...</a></description>
